Authors: Nicky Wybouw, Thomas Van Leeuwen, Wannes Dermauw
Title:
A massive incorporation of microbial genes into the genome of
Tetranychus urticae, a polyphagous arthropod herbivore
Keywords:
lateral gene transfer, inositol
phosporylceramide-synthase, glycosyl hydrolase family 16, galactose
mutarotase, methylenetetrahydrofolate dehydrogenase
Abstract:
A number of horizontally transferred genes (HTGs) have
been identified in the two-spotted spider mite Tetranychus urticae, a
chelicerate herbivore. However, the genome of this mite species has at
present not been thoroughly mined for the presence of HTGs. Here, we
performed a systematic screen of HTGs in the T. urticae genome using the
h-index metric. Our results not only validated previously identified
HTGs but also uncovered 25 novel HTGs. In addition to the novel HTGs
with a predicted biochemical function in carbohydrate, lipid and folate
metabolism, we also identified HTGs that code for a ketopantoate
hydroxymethyltransferase and a pantoate Î²-alanine ligase. In plants and
bacteria, both genes are essential for vitamin B5 biosynthesis and their
presence in the mite genome strongly suggests that spider mites, similar
to Bemisia tabaci and nematodes, can synthesize their own vitamin B5. We
further show that HTGs were physically embedded within the mite genome
and are expressed in different life stages. By screening chelicerate
genomes and transcriptomes, we were able to estimate the evolutionary
histories of these HTGs during chelicerate evolution. Our study suggests
that horizontal gene transfer has made a significant and underestimated
impact on the metabolic repertoire of plant feeding spider mites.
